citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection the outdoor gravel portion of the sheltered facility were muddy and contained an accumulation of
fecal material. The dogs housed in the enclosures were completely soiled with mud and organic debris covering the
entirety of their bodies.
The licensee stated that the facility has not had the fecal matter removed for approximately a week. With the current rain
and not spot cleaning daily, it has made the gravel portion of the enclosures inadequate to keep the animals housed from
being soiled.
Without regular spot cleaning daily and maintaining adequate gravel, it poses a risk of causing soiling of the animals and
increased disease hazards. The licensee shall implement a proactive cleaning regimen and additional aggregate to
prevent soiling of the animals housed.
To be corrected by 12.24.23

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection there was a significant accumulation of rodent feces in the washdown below the enclosures on the
indoor portion of the sheltered facility. The smell of rodent urine was very pronounced upon entering and walking
throughout the indoor portion of the sheltered facility. The pest control section in the POVC indicated the use of traps.
Traps or other methods of rodent control were not observed in the facility.
Rodent infestation can cause health and well-being issues to the animals housed and contaminate feed sources. The
licensee shall consult the POVC to implement the appropriate rodent control method as to minimize the rodent population.
To be correct by 12.29.23
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Licensee.
n

narrative:
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At time of inspection the outdoor gravel portion of the sheltered facility were muddy and contained an accumulation of 
fecal material. The dogs housed in the enclosures were completely soiled with mud and organic debris covering the 
entirety of their bodies.  
The licensee stated that the facility has not had the fecal matter removed for approximately a week. With the current rain 
and not spot cleaning daily, it has made the gravel portion of the enclosures inadequate to keep the animals housed from 
being soiled. 
Without regular spot cleaning daily and maintaining adequate gravel, it poses a risk of causing soiling of the animals and 
increased disease hazards. The licensee shall implement a proactive cleaning regimen and additional aggregate to 
prevent soiling of the animals housed.  
 
To be corrected by 12.24.23 
3.11(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At time of inspection there was a significant accumulation of rodent feces in the washdown below the enclosures on the 
indoor portion of the sheltered facility. The smell of rodent urine was very pronounced upon entering and walking 
throughout the indoor portion of the sheltered facility. The pest control section in the POVC indicated the use of traps. 
Traps or other methods of rodent control were not observed in the facility. 
Rodent infestation can cause health and well-being issues to the animals housed and contaminate feed sources. The 
licensee shall consult the POVC to implement the appropriate rodent control method as to minimize the rodent population.  
 
To be correct by 12.29.23 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Licensee.
